user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FDGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_FDGetInfo(osal_id_t filedes, OS_file_prop_t *fd_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    OS_object_token_t   token;
    int32               return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(fd_prop);

    memset(fd_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_file_prop_t));

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, filedes, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_stream_table, token);

        if (record->name_entry != NULL)
        {
            strncpy(fd_prop->Path, record->name_entry, sizeof(fd_prop->Path) - 1);
        }
        fd_prop->User    = record->creator;
        fd_prop->IsValid = true;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_FDGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_stream_table
...
typedef struct
{
    char      Path[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    osal_id_t User;
    uint8     IsValid; /* For backward compatibility -- always true if OS_FDGetInfo returned true */
} OS_file_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the provided function and the related definitions for uses of known compiler language extensions (examples: __attribute__, __builtin_*, __extension__, __typeof__, statement-expressions ({ ... }), inline assembler (__asm__), GCC nested functions, __thread, long long where not supported, compiler-specific keywords like __inline__ or __declspec, or variadic macro extensions). None of these appear in the target function or the related symbols. The code uses standard C constructs: typedef-based integer types (int32, uint8), standard library calls (memset, strncpy), macros that expand to ordinary expressions (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET), pointer-to-const declaration (extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_stream_table), and boolean-like assignment (fd_prop->IsValid = true) which is a normal constant assignment (the boolean literal itself is a standard C99 feature when stdbool.h is used, or could be a project-defined macro). No compiler-specific tokens or GCC/MSVC extensions are present in the shown code. Therefore there are no fragments that require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
